skill.name: esm
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for protein language models including ESM3 (generative multimodal protein design across sequence, structure, and function) and ESM C (efficient protein embeddings and representations). Use this skill when working with protein sequences, structures, or function prediction; designing novel proteins; generating protein embeddings; performing inverse folding; or conducting protein engineering tasks. Supports both local model usage and cloud-based Forge API for scalable inference.

security_audit.summary: No credential access, environment harvesting, or exfiltration patterns were found. The content is documentation and example code for protein modeling workflows and API usage.

content.user_title: Design proteins with ESM3 and ESM C
content.value_statement: Protein modeling workflows can be complex and fragmented. This skill provides clear, end to end guidance for sequence, structure, function, and embedding tasks.
actual_capabilities: Generate protein sequences from masked prompts with ESM3
Predict 3D structure from sequences using ESM3
Design sequences from target structures with inverse folding
Create protein embeddings with ESM C models
Run batch generation with the Forge API client
limitations: Requires installing the ESM SDK and model weights
Forge API usage requires a valid token and network access
Local inference needs sufficient GPU memory for large models
Results are predictive and need biological validation

use_cases.title: Design sequence variants
use_cases.description: Generate and screen sequence variants with controlled diversity and structure checks.

use_cases.title: Embed and cluster sequences
use_cases.description: Create embeddings and cluster large protein datasets for similarity analysis.

use_cases.title: Function guided design
use_cases.description: Generate proteins with function annotations and iterate with structure prediction.

prompt_templates.title: Complete a sequence
prompt_templates.scenario: Fill masked residues in a protein
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete this masked protein sequence using ESM3 and explain the settings: MPRT___KEND.

prompt_templates.title: Predict structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Use ESM3 to predict structure for this sequence and summarize the output format.

prompt_templates.title: Create embeddings
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to create ESM C embeddings for a list of sequences and note shape expectations.

prompt_templates.title: Batch Forge design
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide an async Forge API workflow to generate 50 variants with rate limiting and retries.

output_examples.input: Design a 200 residue enzyme with function conditioning and outline the workflow.
output: Select ESM3 model and set sequence length to 200 residues
Add function annotation with start and end positions
Review function annotations and validate experimentally

best_practices: Start with smaller models for quick iteration
Use rate limiting and retries for Forge API calls
Validate designed proteins with structure prediction
anti_patterns: Treat generated sequences as experimentally validated
Use large models for every prototype task
Ignore rate limits during batch generation

faq.question: Which environments are compatible?
faq.answer: Works with Python and the ESM SDK on CPU or GPU, plus Forge API access if you use cloud models.

faq.question: What are the practical limits?
faq.answer: Limits depend on model size, sequence length, GPU memory, and Forge API rate limits.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes. The examples include batch, async, and caching patterns for pipeline integration.

faq.question: Does it access my data?
faq.answer: The skill is documentation only and does not access files or transmit data.

faq.question: What if generation fails?
faq.answer: Use the error handling and retry patterns and validate model selection and inputs.

faq.question: How does it compare to ESM2?
faq.answer: ESM C is a drop in replacement with faster inference and improved embedding quality.
